newsitem.title: UK: Metals Outlook-Rally set to resume, funds mobilise.
newsitem.headline: Metals Outlook-Rally set to resume, funds mobilise.

text.p: A New Year rally in base metals stalled temporarily towards the end of last week but traders predict it may resume in coming days, citing a reawakened investment fund interest.
Impressive gains last week drove zinc to 23-month highs and aluminium to eight-month peaks, as well as underscoring tin and nickel which traded at their best for four months.
"It definitely had a better feel to it - my only caution is that volumes, generally, are not large. Turnovers are on a bit of a plateau at the moment," one trader said.
All London Metal Exchange (LME) metal prices have recorded substantial gains so far in 1997 from end-1996 levels, ranging from four percent for lead to nearly 16 percent for nickel.
"There was a bit of selling around at the back-end (of last week), just the usual profit-taking," the trader said.
Traders expect further consolidation on technical grounds in the short-term, but expect buyers to be back in soon, especially as physical business increases in momentum towards the end of the month.
Copper prices, which concluded at $2,248 a tonne on Friday, are seen re-testing $2,280 prior to driving above $2,300 if the current technical tightness worsens.

Aluminium finished last week at $1,607, and really needs to break $1,625 - a double top on the charts. The booming zinc market concluded a barnstorming week at $1,137 and now has $1,200 in its sights.
Meanwhile, analysts said there are longer-term implications for prices to be gathered from last week, notably the stirrings of speculative fund involvement.
"The word on the street is don't be short commodities for 1997' and its quite clear that commodity funds have been active in these early days," Nick Moore of the Flemings Global Mining Group said.
So far, funds have only tipped their toes into the water, but their potential is significantly higher.
Equity markets are bouyant at present, with New York hitting record highs last week, but any signs of bourses faltering could result in asset re-allocation towards commodities, others said.
Last week also saw some banks issuing metal call warrants
